children.name: find out a2
children.definition: find out to get information about sth, either by chance or by deliberately trying to get it:tìm ra, phát hiện ra
examples: ▪ ‘do you have these shoes in size 8?’ ‘i’m not sure - i’ll just go and find out.’
▪ when we found out the price we were shocked.
find out what/ where/ whether etc
▪ i’ll go and find out which platform the train leaves from.
▪ dad was really mad at me when he found out where i’d been.
find out about
▪ he’s trying to find out about japanese classes in the area.
find out something/ find something out
▪ could you find out his address for me, please?
▪ ‘john’s been married twice.’ ‘how did you find that out?’
find out (that)
▪ she found out that her husband was having an affair.

children.name: discover b1
children.definition: discover to find sth out, especially something that is surprising or sth that is difficult to find out.discoveris more formal thanfindout:phát hiện, khám phá ra
examples: ▪ fire officers are still trying to discover the cause of the fire.
discover (that)
▪ i began to learn the guitar, and discovered that i was pretty good at it.
▪ she discovered the job wasn’t as easy as it might seem.
discover how/ why/ what etc
▪ they never discovered who the murderer was.

children.name: hear b1
children.definition: hear to know about sth because sb has told you, you have read about it, seen it on television etc:nghe nói
examples: ▪ ‘nina’s quit her job.’ ‘yes, so i’ve heard.’
hear about
▪ how did you hear about our company?
▪ we’ve heard such a lot about you from our daughter.
hear (that)
▪ i hear you’re moving to toronto.
hear whether/if
▪ when will you hear whether you’ve got the job?
hear what/ why/ how etc
▪ i suppose you’ve heard what happened?

children.name: see b2
children.definition: see especiallyspokento get the information that you want by going somewhere to look, or by doing sth and noticing what happens:xem xem, tìm xem, coi xem
examples: ▪ ‘is he ready yet?’ ‘i don’t know - i’ll go and see.’
see if/ whether
▪ see if the rice is done while you’re in the kitchen, will you?
see how/ where/ what etc
▪ can you see who’s at the door?
▪ let’s see what happens if we add some oil.

children.name: find b1
children.definition: find especiallywrittento find out a fact or find out that something is true, especially byaskingquestions:phát hiện ra
examples: find (that)
we found that, despite their poverty, very few people wanted to leave the area.
researchers found that smokers were more likely to get depressed than non-smokers.

children.name: be told b2
children.definition: be told to find out about sth because sb tells you:được biết
examples: be told (that)
▪ he was told that anna had left some time ago.
▪ visitors have been told the building will be used as a museum.
so i’m toldspoken
▪ ‘is it true that she’s moving to hollywood?’ ‘so i’m told.’

children.name: learn b1
children.definition: learn to find out sth because sb tells you, you read it somewhere etc:biết
examples: ▪ i doubt if we will ever learn the truth.
learn of/about
▪ she learned of her mother’s death when it was announced on the radio.
learn (that)
▪ several months ago, mcnair learned that he had cancer.

children.name: gather u
children.definition: gather to know a piece of information because that is what you hear people saying and not because you have been told it directly:nghe nói
examples: gather (that)
▪ i gather you’ve decided not to resign after all.
▪ despite my limited spanish, i gathered that there was a problem with my passport.
from what sb can gatheraccording to what i have found out
▪ from what i can gather, there has been fighting further down the valley.

children.name: come to sb’s attention x
children.definition: come to sb’s attention/notice formal if sth such as a problem or a mistake comes to sb’s attention or notice, that person finds out about it, especially because someone else tells them about it:được chú ý
examples: ▪ illegal trading first came to the attention of top management in late april.
come to sb’s attention/ notice that
▪ it has come to my notice that your account is overdrawn by £200.

children.name: hear on the grapevine x
children.definition: hear through/ on the grapevine to find out about sth because the information has been passed on from one person to another in conversation: nghe đồn
examples: ▪ ‘how did you find out she was leaving?’ ‘i heard it through the grapevine.’
hear through/ on the grapevine that
▪ i heard on the grapevine that josie and tom are expecting a baby.

children.name: to find out sth new or secret
find out a2
children.definition: find outphát hiện
examples: ▪ he just had to hope he’d get away with it and that nobody would find out.
▪ she doesn’t want people to find out her age.
▪ you read her diary? just make sure she never finds out!
find out what/ why/ how etc
▪ dad was furious when he found out where i was living.
find out about
▪ it’s a surprise party, so i don’t want her to find out about it.
find out (that)
▪ it was three months before my parents found out i’d been going out with peter.
find sb outuk find out someone’s secret
▪ it won’t work. someone’s bound to find you out eventually.

children.name: uncover x
children.definition: uncover/unearth to find out information that has been deliberately kept secret, especially while you are studying or examining a particular subject:tìm ra, phát hiện
examples: ▪ detectives have uncovered a plan to smuggle illegal weapons into the country.
▪ lawyers unearthed evidence that he held several bank accounts.

children.name: dig up x
children.definition: dig up to find out information by searching carefully for it, especially information about someone’s past that they have deliberately tried to keep secret:đào bới
examples: dig something up/dig up something
▪ i wanted to dig a few more facts up for my article.
dig up dirt on somebodyfind out something bad about someone
▪ politicians try to dig up dirt on their opponents.
dig something up on somebody
▪ he wanted as much evidence as could be dug up on the girl.

children.name: get at u
children.definition: get at to find sth out, especially the truth about a situation, or facts that sb has tried to hide:
examples: ▪ it’s hard to get at the facts when people are afraid to speak out.
▪ he was a good reporter, who wanted to get at the truth and present it without bias.

children.name: get wind of x
children.definition: get wind of informal to find out about a situation or sth that is going to happen, especially when it is supposed to be secret:nghe phong phanh
examples: ▪ reporters somehow got wind of the fact that carr was going to be arrested.

children.name: get wise to x
children.definition: get wise to informal to find out about something such as a trick or an illegal activity:nhận biết (một trò lừa, sự bất chính)
examples: ▪ the police parked an empty patrol car there to reduce speeding, but drivers got wise to it pretty quickly.

children.name: to find out the exact cause of sth
determine c1
children.definition: determine to find out the exact details or facts about sth, especially by using technical methods and equipment:xác định
examples: ▪ ‘web police’ are often able to determine the exact source of unwanted mailings on the internet.
determine what/ why/ how etc
▪ quizzes are used to determine how much material students have learned.
determine that
▪ a survey of traffic accidents determined that seat belts reduced serious injuries by up to 90%.

children.name: establish c2
children.definition: establish to find out facts that will prove how sth happened or what caused it:xác định
examples: ▪ we haven’t yet established the cause of the accident.
establish that
▪ it was quickly established that several members of the crew had been negligent.
establish how/ where/ why etc
▪ they are carrying out research to establish exactly why so many species of songbird are disappearing.

children.name: identify b2
children.definition: identify to find out exactly what the cause or origin of sth is:xác định
examples: ▪ after years of research, scientists have identified the virus that is responsible for the disease.
▪ experts are examining the wreckage, but the cause of the accident has not yet been identified.

children.name: pinpoint c2
children.definition: pinpoint to find out exactly what sth is, when sth happened, or what exactly is causing sth:xác định
examples: ▪ investigators are trying to pinpoint the cause of the fire.
▪ mechanics are having difficulty pinpointing the problem.
pinpoint what/ how/ when etc
▪ the test is meant to pinpoint which types of jobs you are suited for.

children.name: to find out info from sb
find out a2
children.definition: find out to find out information from someone by asking them questions or by forcing them to tell you: tìm hiểu
examples: ▪ will you see if you can find anything out about sandy?
▪ ‘did you find out her views on the subject?’ ‘no, she wouldn’t tell me.’
find out what/ how/ when etc
▪ he asked me to find out what your plans are after you leave.

children.name: get sth out of x
children.definition: get sth out of informal to find out a particular piece of information from sb, especially by forcing them to tell you:tra hỏi
examples: ▪ jed admitted he’d been at the scene, but that’s all i could get out of him.
▪ we’ll get the truth out of her sooner or later.

children.name: get information a2
children.definition: get information to find out sth from a person, a book, the internet etc: kiếm thông tin
examples: ▪ to get more information, telephone or contact us on our website.
▪ you will be able to get most of the information you need from the school library.
get information about/ on
▪ i’ve written to the tourist information centre to get some information about the area.

children.name: extract x
children.definition: extract formal to find out information from sb who does not want to give it, by asking them questions or by using physical force:moi tin
examples: ▪ police questioned the prisoner for several hours, but were unable to extract any further information.
extract sth from sb
▪ the court ruled that her confession had been unlawfully extracted from her.

children.name: worm sth out of x
children.definition: worm sth out of sb to find out information from sb who is unwilling to give it, especially by being clever, making them feel they can trust you etc:thuyết phục ai nói ra
examples: ▪ he didn’t want to tell me her name but i managed to worm it out of him.

children.name: drag sth out of x
children.definition: drag sth out of to get information from sb who does not want to tell you it, especially by asking a lot of questions:cạy miệng
examples: ▪ if she doesn’t want to tell you, there’s no point in trying to drag it out of her.

children.name: to try to find out sth private or personal
snoop x
children.definition: snoop to try to find out about sb’s private affairs, especially by secretly looking in their house, examining their possessions etc:rình mò
examples: ▪ bob caught her snooping through the papers on his desk.
snoop on
▪ technology is making it easier to snoop on just about anybody.
snoop around/ aboutbritish
▪ what are you doing snooping around in my room?

children.name: pry x
children.definition: pry to try to find out about sb’s private life by asking a lot of personal questions in a way that people find rude or annoying:soi mói
examples: my son hasn’t given us a reason for his divorce, and we don’t want to pry.
pry into
employers shouldn’t try to pry into what a person does in the privacy of their own home.

children.name: nose around x
children.definition: nose around/ aboutuk  informal to look around a place, especially sb’s home or office, to try to find out things that do not really concern you:sục sạo
examples: ▪ the kids were nosing around in the attic and found a box of old photos.
nose around an office/ room/house etc
▪ i got suspicious when i found him nosing around my office early one morning.

children.name: discovery b2
children.definition: discovery sth such as a new fact or method that someone has found out, either accidentally or as a result of careful examination or questions:khám phá, phát hiện
examples: ▪ at first i did not realize the importance of my discovery.
discovery that
▪ an investigation was ordered after the discovery that $89,000 was missing from the account.
discovery about
▪ the depletion of the ozone layer has been one of the most dramatic discoveries about our planet in recent years.

children.name: finding x
children.definition: finding the information that sb has found out as a result of examining sth carefully:phát hiện
examples: ▪ one of the findings was that many cases of ‘stomach flu’ are caused by improper cooking of food.
▪ the police force has had its image severely battered by the commission’s findings.
